awd_titl_txt: CC* Integration: Enhancement and deployment of LDM7 for scientific data distribution
awd_abstract_narration:
The University Corporation for Atmospheric Research (UCAR)  distributes scientific weather
data from instruments and simulations to its 250 consortium member institutions via the Internet
Data Distribution (IDD) system. The software program used for this data distribution is called Local Data Manager
(LDM). LDM6, the current deployed version, has been in use since 2003. This project seeks to
create a higher performing solution for real-time scientific data distribution by leveraging Software Defined
Networking and OpenFlow technologies.

This project seeks to  (i) deploy LDM7 on multiple campuses after provisioning
VLANs across campuses and regionals, and connecting them to a multipoint VLAN across Internet2?s
network, (ii) add new features for security and control-plane to LDM7, (iii) integrate LDM7
with an SDN controller (OESS) client for automated addition/deletion of VLAN segments to a
multipoint VLAN, (iv) collect information, and develop tools for simplifying VLAN provisioning
and testing L2 path connectivity and performance using perfSONAR and other tools, and (v)
run extensive tests of LDM7 for performance and reliability.

CC* Project Outcomes Report

A continuing trend in many scientific disciplines is the growth of the volume of data collected by scientific instruments and the desire to rapidly and efficiently distribute this data to the scientific community. As an example, the University Corporation for Atmospheric Research (UCAR) at Boulder Colorado, distributes 30 different types of meteorological data (e.g., surface observations, radar data, satellite imagery, wind profiler data, lightning data, and high-resolution computer-model output) to over 570 sites in 217 domains. Approximately 420,000 data products comprising 50 gigabytes (GB) are generated each hour.

To address the general issue of fast distribution of scientific data to multiple sites, this project investigated a high-performance, reliable, secure network solution using Software Defined Networking (SDN) to simultaneously multicast the data to the sites. This project had the following outcomes.

The project designed a new service architecture to deliver scientific data to subscribers. This architecture supported reliable file-stream multicasting over an SDN-enabled network. The design was analyzed and validated through a realistic simulation performed on NSF's Chameleon Infrastructure. Chameleon, a large-scale, deeply reconfigurable experimental platform, was built to support Computer Sciences systems research. It provided the perfect environment for validating the system design and evaluating trade-offs and the impact of various network factors, including the number of subscribers, the packet loss rate, and available bandwidth.

Based on the simulation results, we implemented a trial deployment on Internet2, which included eight university campuses connected via regional Research-and-Education Networks (RENs). The trial deployment developed a novel performance monitoring system to collect real-time data regarding the performance of the multicast-enabled delivery system. The deployment allowed us to evaluate the newly designed system's performance for delivering the weather-related data sets. Our experimentation prompted us to develop a novel, control-plane protocol to support users to add and drop subscriptions to data products and reconfigure the SDN controllers as needed.

Our experiments showed that the new system achieved an almost 22-fold improvement in delivery time. The experiments also showed that the bandwidth requirements to achieve satisfactory throughput were reduced by 90%.

Realizing that the integrity of scientific data is critical, the project also developed a mechanism to ensure the integrity of the data delivered to subscribers. With multicast networks, there is the potential that a compromised or malicious subscriber could potentially cause tampered data to be delivered to other subscribers. To address this concern, we developed an appropriate asymmetric cryptographic approach that thwarts this threat. Our implementation achieved the appropriate trade-off between security and performance.

This project supported several master's students (including three women) and a Ph.D. student who finished their Ph.D. in 2022. Their dissertation research yielded many of the key results of this project.
